intro: Narcissus romieuxii subsp. jacquemoudii, commonly known as the Jacquemoud's daffodil, is a rare and ornamental plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It is characterized by its striking yellow flowers with a cup-shaped corona, typical of the daffodil genus. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–50 centimeters, with narrow, grass-like leaves. It prefers well-drained soil and full sun, thriving in cooler climates. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
